definitions.definition: showing a lack of thought, understanding, or judgement
definitions.sensetop: it is silly to do somethingit is silly of somebody to do something

examples.text: a silly idea/question/name
That was a **silly thing** to do!
It sounds silly, I know, but think about it.
Her work is full of silly mistakes.
‘I can walk home.’ ‘Don't be silly—it's much too far!’
The answers they give are plain silly.
You silly boy!
It would have been silly to pretend that I wasn't upset.
examples.contextForm: it is silly to do something

examples.text: It would be silly of me to say no.
examples.contextForm: it is silly of somebody to do something

examples.text: How silly of me to expect them to help!

definitions.definition: stupid or embarrassing, especially in a way that is more typical of a child than an adult

examples.text: a silly sense of humour
a silly game
He would never dance in case he **looked silly**.
I feel silly in these clothes.
She had a silly grin on her face.
This is getting silly! I think we had all better calm down.
We had to wear these **silly little** hats.
Why worry about a **silly thing** like that?
I remember being bored stiff during my entire time at school.
She enjoys it. Everyone else is bored silly.
He walked along, bored out of his mind.
She was alone all day and bored to death.
You must be bored stiff stuck at home all day.
Personally, I was bored to death.

definitions.definition: to drink, laugh, shout, etc. so much that you cannot behave in a sensible way
to not be honest with somebody, especially in order to gain an advantage over them

examples.text: Don't play silly games with me; I know you did it.

definitions.definition: to behave in a stupid and annoying way

examples.text: Stop playing silly buggers and give me a hand with this!

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘deserving of pity or sympathy’): alteration of dialect seely ‘happy’, later ‘innocent, feeble’, from a West Germanic base meaning ‘luck, happiness’. The sense ‘foolish’ developed via the stages ‘feeble’ and ‘unsophisticated, ignorant’.
